text: express expected value μij\mu_{ij} follows: μij=(1−βb()j)(f(tij|ξ,α)−f(0|ξ,α))+f(0|ξ,α)+Wiγ−⟨W¯,γ⟩ \begin{aligned} \mu_{ij} &= (1 - \beta_{b()j}) \left ( f(t_{ij} | \xi, \alpha) - f(0 | \xi, \alpha) \right ) + f(0 | \xi, \alpha) + W_i \gamma - \langle \overline{W}_i, \gamma \rangle \end{aligned} b()b() study arm patient ii, βkj\beta_{kj} reduction decline study arm kk (k=1,…,Kk = 1, \ldots, K) relative control arm k=1k = 1. appropriately constrain parameter space, express βkj\beta_{kj} parameters terms latent θ(k−1)(j−1)\theta_{(k - 1)(j - 1)} parameters follows: βkj={0k=1 j=1θ(k−1)(j−1)k∈{2,…,K} j∈{2,…,J} \begin{aligned} \beta_{kj} = \begin{cases} 0 & k = 1 \text{ } j = 1 \\ \theta_{(k-1)(j-1)} & k \\{2, \ldots, K\} \text{ } j \\{2, \ldots, J\} \end{cases} \end{aligned} model estimates latent parameters θ11,…,θ(K−1)(J−1)\theta_{11}, \ldots, \theta_{(K - 1)(J - 1)} maximum likelihood.

title: Usage
text: package functions expect tidy longitudinal data one row per subject visit columns patient outcome, continuous time, indicator variables, optional covariates. pmrm package functions simulate datasets supported model. outcome column can missing values, column must missing values.1 output datasets includes important information supply modeling function.
code: library(pmrm) set.seed(0) simulation <- pmrm_simulate_decline_proportional(   patients = 500,   visit_times = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4),   tau = 0.25,   alpha = c(0, 0.7, 1, 1.4, 1.6),   beta = c(0, 0.2, 0.35),   gamma = c(-1, 1) ) simulation$y[c(2L, 3L, 12L, 13L, 14L, 15L)] <- NA_real_ simulation[, c("y", "t", "patient", "visit", "arm")] #> # A tibble: 2,500 × 5 #>         y     t patient   visit   arm   #>     <dbl> <dbl> <chr>     <ord>   <ord> #>  1  2.20   0    patient_1 visit_1 arm_1 #>  2 NA      1.47 patient_1 visit_2 arm_1 #>  3 NA      1.90 patient_1 visit_3 arm_1 #>  4  1.93   2.73 patient_1 visit_4 arm_1 #>  5  3.33   4.04 patient_1 visit_5 arm_1 #>  6 -4.75   0    patient_2 visit_1 arm_2 #>  7  0.271  1.16 patient_2 visit_2 arm_2 #>  8  1.95   1.97 patient_2 visit_3 arm_2 #>  9  1.99   3.09 patient_2 visit_4 arm_2 #> 10  3.60   4.45 patient_2 visit_5 arm_2 #> # ℹ 2,490 more rows

title: Usage
text: fit model, simply supply preprocessed dataset optionally knot vector xi (usually just contains scheduled times visits). package powered RTMB package, model fitting process runs fast. fitted model object parameter estimates, standard errors, model constants, convergence status, raw RTMB objects, information. estimates:2 Just estimates actual parameters, omitting functions parameters:3

title: Usage
text: Model-checking involved topic, pmrm go tremendous depth. Instead, offers basic checks fitted model object. goal guide intuition high-level understanding. First, check convergence code. 0 indicates convergence, 1 indicates model diverged local minimum otherwise reached (e.g. case saddle point). Next, may wish check parameter estimates standard errors make sense. Also, please check odd behavior fitted spline f(x|ξ,α)f(x | \xi, \alpha).  tough cases, spline may flatten knot boundaries twist strange directions. notice strange fitted spline divergent model, may wish experiment different knot placement hand-pick initial values vertical knot distances alpha. latter can sometimes help stabilize theta (especially pmrm_model_slowing()) beginning appropriately strict monotone spline. Example: Alternatively, can even tweak one parameters resume original optimization. Finally, may wish fit Bayesian version model using tmbstan check correlations among parameters. Strong pairwise correlations involving α\alpha parameter may indicate spline many knots.
code: fit$optimization$convergence #> [1] 0 str(fit$estimates) #> List of 9 #>  $ alpha : Named num [1:5] 0.0269 0.763 0.9555 1.4059 1.6247 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:5] "1" "2" "3" "4" ... #>  $ theta : num [1:2] 0.249 0.375 #>  $ gamma : num [1:2] -0.954 0.995 #>  $ phi   : num [1:5] 0.0364 0.0134 -0.0022 -0.0399 0.0403 #>  $ rho   : num [1:10] -0.0429 -0.0824 0.0437 -0.0715 -0.0532 ... #>  $ beta  : num [1:3] 0 0.249 0.375 #>  $ sigma : num [1:5] 1.037 1.014 0.998 0.961 1.041 #>  $ Lambda: num [1:5, 1:5] 1 -0.0428 -0.082 0.0436 -0.0712 ... #>  $ Sigma : num [1:5, 1:5] 1.0756 -0.045 -0.0849 0.0434 -0.0768 ... str(fit$standard_errors) #> List of 9 #>  $ alpha : Named num [1:5] 0.0455 0.0637 0.0609 0.063 0.0636 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:5] "1" "2" "3" "4" ... #>  $ theta : num [1:2] 0.0412 0.0402 #>  $ gamma : num [1:2] 0.0206 0.0205 #>  $ phi   : num [1:5] 0.0316 0.0317 0.0318 0.0318 0.0318 #>  $ rho   : num [1:10] 0.0449 0.0451 0.0449 0.0451 0.0449 ... #>  $ beta  : num [1:3] 0 0.0412 0.0402 #>  $ sigma : num [1:5] 0.0328 0.0321 0.0318 0.0306 0.0331 #>  $ Lambda: num [1:5, 1:5] 0 0.0447 0.0446 0.0447 0.0446 ... #>  $ Sigma : num [1:5, 1:5] 0.0681 0.0472 0.0466 0.0447 0.0486 ... knots <- fit$constants$spline_knots curve(fit$spline(x), min(knots), max(knots)) initial <- fit$initial initial$alpha <- c(0, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2)  fit2 <- pmrm_model_decline_proportional(   data = simulation,   outcome = "y",   time = "t",   patient = "patient",   visit = "visit",   arm = "arm",   covariates = ~ w_1 + w_2,   visit_times = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4),   initial = initial # with hand-picked initial alpha ) initial <- fit$final # true parameters from the last fit initial$theta[2] <- 0 # reset a scalar parameter that may have diverged  fit3 <- pmrm_model_decline_proportional(   data = simulation,   outcome = "y",   time = "t",   patient = "patient",   visit = "visit",   arm = "arm",   covariates = ~ w_1 + w_2,   visit_times = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4),   initial = initial # with the modified parameter values ) library(dplyr) library(tmbstan) library(posterior)  # Fit a Bayesian version of the same model. # Increase the number of chains for the Rhat diagnostic to be valid. mcmc <- tmbstan(fit$model, chains = 1, refresh = 10)  # Extract the MCMC draws. draws <- as_draws_df(mcmc) |>   select(starts_with("alpha"), any_of(c("theta", "phi")))  # Plot pairwise correlations among MCMC draws. # Pairs of parameters should not be strongly correlated. # Tight correlations and funneling indicate problems, # such as non-identifiability if you have too many knots. pairs(draws)  # Alternatively, if you have many parameters, you can look at # pairwise linear correlations. However, this may miss # important pathologies. correlations <- cor(samples)[lower.tri(cor(samples))] hist(correlations)

title: Usage
text: Use pmrm_estimates() compute estimates, standard errors, confidence intervals model parameters standard downstream functions parameters. example, active-arm post-baseline treatment effect parameters: visit-specific standard deviations residuals: summary() method produces high-level metrics model comparison.
code: pmrm_estimates(fit, parameter = "theta") #> # A tibble: 2 × 6 #>   parameter arm   estimate standard_error lower upper #>   <chr>     <ord>    <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 theta     arm_2    0.249         0.0412 0.169 0.330 #> 2 theta     arm_3    0.375         0.0402 0.296 0.454 pmrm_estimates(fit, parameter = "sigma", confidence = 0.9) #> # A tibble: 5 × 6 #>   parameter visit   estimate standard_error lower upper #>   <chr>     <ord>      <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 sigma     visit_1    1.04          0.0328 0.983  1.09 #> 2 sigma     visit_2    1.01          0.0321 0.961  1.07 #> 3 sigma     visit_3    0.998         0.0318 0.946  1.05 #> 4 sigma     visit_4    0.961         0.0306 0.911  1.01 #> 5 sigma     visit_5    1.04          0.0331 0.987  1.10 summary(fit) #> # A tibble: 1 × 7 #>   model  parameterization log_likelihood n_observations n_parameters   aic   bic #>   <chr>  <chr>                     <dbl>          <int>        <int> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 decli… proportional             -3556.           2494           24 7159. 7299.

title: Usage
text: pmrm_marginals() returns estimated marginal means study arm visit. continuous time visit given marginals argument pmrm_model_decline_proportional(). Select type = "change" estimates change baseline. Select type = "effect" estimates treatment effect (change baseline active arm minus control arm).

title: Usage
text: package supports predict() method PMRMs. returns expected values, standard errors, confidence intervals outcomes given new data. important columns original data need part new data, except outcome column can entirely absent.
code: predict(fit, data = head(simulation, 5)) #> # A tibble: 5 × 7 #>   arm   visit    time estimate standard_error  lower  upper #>   <ord> <ord>   <dbl>    <dbl>          <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 arm_1 visit_1  0       0.939         0.0476  0.846  1.03  #> 2 arm_1 visit_2  1.47    1.69          0.0521  1.59   1.80  #> 3 arm_1 visit_3  1.90   -1.39          0.0697 -1.52  -1.25  #> 4 arm_1 visit_4  2.73    0.622         0.0609  0.503  0.742 #> 5 arm_1 visit_5  4.04    2.92          0.0690  2.79   3.06

title: Usage
text: pmrm supports S3 method plot() generic. method plot.pmrm_fit() visually compares model data. default plot shows: Raw estimates confidence intervals data, points vertical line segments. Model-based marginal means confidence intervals, horizontal line segments boxes around . Model-based predictions confidence bands, continuous lines shaded regions.  can customize plot: example, compare fitted disease progression trajectory across treatment arms.
code: plot(   fit,   show_predictions = TRUE # Defaults to FALSE because predictions take extra time. ) plot(   fit,   confidence = 0.9,   show_data = FALSE,   show_predictions = TRUE, # Defaults to FALSE because predictions take extra time.   facet = FALSE,   alpha = 0.5 )

text: progression model repeated measures (PMRM) longitudinal continuous-time nonlinear model progressive disease. PMRMs designed estimate treatment effect time scale, often appropriate intuitive typical treatment effect outcome scale. package implements frequentist PMRMs Raket (2022) using TMB Kristensen et al. (2016).

title: Internal function to prepare data — pmrm_data
text: data tibble data frame one row per patient visit. See arguments specific requirements data. outcome Character string, name column data numeric outcome variable continuous scale. clinical measure healthy disease severity. Baseline part model, outcome already change baseline. vector outcomes may missing values, either explicit NAs rows data missing one visits. time Character string, name column data numeric time variable continuous scale. time time since enrollment/randomization patient. time value 0 indicate baseline. patient Character string, name column data patient ID. vector numeric, integer, factor, character vector. pmrm automatically converts unordered factor. visit Character string, name column data indicates study visit row. column numeric, integer, factor, character vector. ordered factor highly recommended pmrm levels assumed chronological order. minimum visit must baseline. arm Character string, name column data indicates study arm row. column numeric, integer, factor, character vector. ordered factor highly recommended pmrm automatically converts data[[arm]] ordered factor anyway. minimum level assumed control arm. covariates Partial right-sided formula concomitant terms model covariate adjustment (e.g. age, gender, biomarker status, etc.). include main variables values outcome, time, patient, visit, arm. columns data referenced formula must missing values. Set covariates ~ 0 (default) opt covariate adjustment. intercept term removed model matrix W whether formula begins `~ 0.

title: Internal function to prepare data — pmrm_data
text: tibble class "pmrm_data" one row per patient visit. Rows missing outcomes removed, variables arm visit converted ordered factors (minimum values control arm baseline, respectively), rows sorted patient visit. "labels" attribute named list values arguments outcome, time, visit, arm, covariates.

title: Fit a progression model for repeated measures. — pmrm_model
code: pmrm_model(   data,   outcome,   time,   patient,   visit,   arm,   covariates,   visit_times,   spline_knots,   spline_method,   reml,   hessian,   saddle,   control,   initial_method,   initial,   silent,   slowing,   proportional )

title: Fit a progression model for repeated measures. — pmrm_model
text: data data frame tibble clinical data. outcome Character string, name column data numeric outcome variable continuous scale. clinical measure healthy disease severity. Baseline part model, outcome already change baseline. vector outcomes may missing values, either explicit NAs rows data missing one visits. time Character string, name column data numeric time variable continuous scale. time time since enrollment/randomization patient. time value 0 indicate baseline. patient Character string, name column data patient ID. vector numeric, integer, factor, character vector. pmrm automatically converts unordered factor. visit Character string, name column data indicates study visit row. column numeric, integer, factor, character vector. ordered factor highly recommended pmrm levels assumed chronological order. minimum visit must baseline. arm Character string, name column data indicates study arm row. column numeric, integer, factor, character vector. ordered factor highly recommended pmrm automatically converts data[[arm]] ordered factor anyway. minimum level assumed control arm. covariates Partial right-sided formula concomitant terms model covariate adjustment (e.g. age, gender, biomarker status, etc.). include main variables values outcome, time, patient, visit, arm. columns data referenced formula must missing values. Set covariates ~ 0 (default) opt covariate adjustment. intercept term removed model matrix W whether formula begins `~ 0. visit_times Numeric vector, continuous scheduled time study visit (since randomization). NULL, visit time automatically set set median observed times categorical visit data. spline_knots Numeric vector spline knots continuous scale, including boundary knots. spline_method Character string, spline method use base model. Must "natural" "fmm". See stats::splinefun() details. reml TRUE fit model restricted maximum likelihood (REML), involves integrating fixed effects. FALSE use unrestricted maximum likelihood. reml TRUE, hessian automatically set "never". hessian Character string controlling supply Hessian matrix objective function optimizer stats::nlminb(). Supplying Hessian usually slows optimization may improve convergence cases, particularly saddle points objective function. hessian argument automatically set "never" whenever reml TRUE. hessian argument must one following values: "divergence": first try model without supplying Hessian. model converge, retry supplying Hessian. "never": fit model supply Hessian stats::nlminb(). "always": fit model supply Hessian stats::nlminb(). saddle TRUE check optimization hit saddle point, , treat model fit diverged. FALSE skip check sake speed. control named list control parameters passed directly control argument stats::nlminb(). initial_method Character string, name method computing initial values. Ignored unless initial NULL. Must one following values: "regression": sets spline vertical distances alpha fitted values knots simple linear regression responses versus continuous time. Sets true model parameters 0. "regression_control": like "regression" except use data control group. Sets true model parameters 0. "zero": sets true model parameters 0, including alpha. initial initial named list, pmrm uses list initial parameter values optimization. Otherwise, pmrm automatically computes starting values using method given initial_method argument (see ). initial list, must following named finite numeric elements conforming true parameters defined vignette("models", package = "pmrm"): alpha: vector length spline_knots. theta: proportional models, vector K - 1 elements, K number study arms. non-proportional models, matrix K - 1 rows J - 1 columns, K number study arms J number study visits. gamma: vector V elements, V number columns covariate adjustment model matrix W. unsure V, simply fit test model (e.g. fit <- pmrm_model_decline_proportional(...)) check ncol(fit$constants$W). phi: vector length visit_times (may different length spline_knots). rho: vector J * (J - 1) / 2 elements, J length visit_times. can generate example format list fitting test model (e.g. fit <- pmrm_model_decline_proportional(...)) extracting fit$initial fit$final. silent MakeADFun. slowing TRUE fit slowing model, FALSE fit decline model. proportional TRUE fit proportional model, FALSE fit non-proportional model.

title: Fit a progression model for repeated measures. — pmrm_model
text: "pmrm_fit" object (see "pmrm fit objects" section details).

title: Fit a progression model for repeated measures. — pmrm_model
text: "pmrm_fit" object classed list returned modeling functions. following named elements: data: tibble, input data missing outcomes removed remaining rows sorted patient visit within patient. data special "pmrm_data" class modified user. constants: list fixed quantities data objective function uses optimization. quantities defined modeling simulation vignettes pmrm package. n_visits positive integer vector number non-missing outcomes patient. options: list low-level model-fitting options RTMB. objective: objective function optimization. Returns minus log likelihood model. arguments (1) list constants, (2) list model parameters. arguments strict formatting requirements. (1), see constants element fitted model object. (2), see initial final. model$fn (model element fitted model object) contains copy objective function takes parameter list. (constants closure model$fn.) model: model object returned RTMB::MakeADFun() compiled objective function gradient. elements can supplied optimization routine R stats::nlminb(). optimization: object returned stats::nlminb() perform optimization estimates parameters. optimization$convergence equals 0 model converges. report: object returned RTMB::sdreport() information standard deviations model parameters. initial: list model parameters initial values. Includes true parameters like theta alpha include derived parameters like beta sigma. can supply list similarly formatted initial values initial argument modeling function choose. final: list model parameter estimates optimization, including derived parameters like beta sigma. format exactly initial (see ) help deal divergent model fits. model fit diverged want try resume optimization slightly better values, can modify values final supply result initial argument modeling function. estimates: full list parameter estimates, including derived parameters standard_errors: list parameter standard errors. metrics: list high-level model metrics, including: n_observations: positive integer scalar, number non-missing observations data. n_parameters: positive integer scalar, number model parameters data. Includes true parameters like theta excludes downstream functions parameters beta. log_likelihood: numeric scalar, maximized log likelihood fitted model. aic: numeric scalar, Akaike information criterion fitted model. bic: numeric scalar, Bayesian information criterion fitted model. spline: vectorized function accepts continuous time x returns value fitted spline f(x | spline_knots, alpha) time x given user-specified knots spline_knots maximum likelihood estimates alpha. Useful diagnosing strange behavior fitted spline. spline behaves oddly, especially extrapolating beyond range time points, please consider adjusting knots spline_knots initial values alpha refitting model.

title: Fit the proportional decline model. — pmrm_model_decline_proportional
text: data data frame tibble clinical data. outcome Character string, name column data numeric outcome variable continuous scale. clinical measure healthy disease severity. Baseline part model, outcome already change baseline. vector outcomes may missing values, either explicit NAs rows data missing one visits. time Character string, name column data numeric time variable continuous scale. time time since enrollment/randomization patient. time value 0 indicate baseline. patient Character string, name column data patient ID. vector numeric, integer, factor, character vector. pmrm automatically converts unordered factor. visit Character string, name column data indicates study visit row. column numeric, integer, factor, character vector. ordered factor highly recommended pmrm levels assumed chronological order. minimum visit must baseline. arm Character string, name column data indicates study arm row. column numeric, integer, factor, character vector. ordered factor highly recommended pmrm automatically converts data[[arm]] ordered factor anyway. minimum level assumed control arm. covariates Partial right-sided formula concomitant terms model covariate adjustment (e.g. age, gender, biomarker status, etc.). include main variables values outcome, time, patient, visit, arm. columns data referenced formula must missing values. Set covariates ~ 0 (default) opt covariate adjustment. intercept term removed model matrix W whether formula begins `~ 0. visit_times Numeric vector, continuous scheduled time study visit (since randomization). NULL, visit time automatically set set median observed times categorical visit data. spline_knots Numeric vector spline knots continuous scale, including boundary knots. spline_method Character string, spline method use base model. Must "natural" "fmm". See stats::splinefun() details. reml TRUE fit model restricted maximum likelihood (REML), involves integrating fixed effects. FALSE use unrestricted maximum likelihood. reml TRUE, hessian automatically set "never". hessian Character string controlling supply Hessian matrix objective function optimizer stats::nlminb(). Supplying Hessian usually slows optimization may improve convergence cases, particularly saddle points objective function. hessian argument automatically set "never" whenever reml TRUE. hessian argument must one following values: "divergence": first try model without supplying Hessian. model converge, retry supplying Hessian. "never": fit model supply Hessian stats::nlminb(). "always": fit model supply Hessian stats::nlminb(). saddle TRUE check optimization hit saddle point, , treat model fit diverged. FALSE skip check sake speed. control named list control parameters passed directly control argument stats::nlminb(). initial_method Character string, name method computing initial values. Ignored unless initial NULL. Must one following values: "regression": sets spline vertical distances alpha fitted values knots simple linear regression responses versus continuous time. Sets true model parameters 0. "regression_control": like "regression" except use data control group. Sets true model parameters 0. "zero": sets true model parameters 0, including alpha. initial initial named list, pmrm uses list initial parameter values optimization. Otherwise, pmrm automatically computes starting values using method given initial_method argument (see ). initial list, must following named finite numeric elements conforming true parameters defined vignette("models", package = "pmrm"): alpha: vector length spline_knots. theta: vector K - 1 elements, K number study arms. gamma: vector V elements, V number columns covariate adjustment model matrix W. unsure V, simply fit test model (e.g. fit <- pmrm_modepmrm_model_decline_proportionall_decline(...)) check ncol(fit$constants$W). phi: vector length visit_times (may different length spline_knots). rho: vector J * (J - 1) / 2 elements, J length visit_times. can generate example format list fitting test model (e.g. fit <- pmrm_model_decline_proportional(...)) extracting fit$initial fit$final. silent MakeADFun.

text: "pmrm_fit" object classed list returned modeling functions. following named elements: data: tibble, input data missing outcomes removed remaining rows sorted patient visit within patient. data special "pmrm_data" class modified user. constants: list fixed quantities data objective function uses optimization. quantities defined modeling simulation vignettes pmrm package. n_visits positive integer vector number non-missing outcomes patient. options: list low-level model-fitting options RTMB. objective: objective function optimization. Returns minus log likelihood model. arguments (1) list constants, (2) list model parameters. arguments strict formatting requirements. (1), see constants element fitted model object. (2), see initial final. model$fn (model element fitted model object) contains copy objective function takes parameter list. (constants closure model$fn.) model: model object returned RTMB::MakeADFun() compiled objective function gradient. elements can supplied optimization routine R stats::nlminb(). optimization: object returned stats::nlminb() perform optimization estimates parameters. optimization$convergence equals 0 model converges. report: object returned RTMB::sdreport() information standard deviations model parameters. initial: list model parameters initial values. Includes true parameters like theta alpha include derived parameters like beta sigma. can supply list similarly formatted initial values initial argument modeling function choose. final: list model parameter estimates optimization, including derived parameters like beta sigma. format exactly initial (see ) help deal divergent model fits. model fit diverged want try resume optimization slightly better values, can modify values final supply result initial argument modeling function. estimates: full list parameter estimates, including derived parameters standard_errors: list parameter standard errors. metrics: list high-level model metrics, including: n_observations: positive integer scalar, number non-missing observations data. n_parameters: positive integer scalar, number model parameters data. Includes true parameters like theta excludes downstream functions parameters beta. log_likelihood: numeric scalar, maximized log likelihood fitted model. aic: numeric scalar, Akaike information criterion fitted model. bic: numeric scalar, Bayesian information criterion fitted model. spline: vectorized function accepts continuous time x returns value fitted spline f(x | spline_knots, alpha) time x given user-specified knots spline_knots maximum likelihood estimates alpha. Useful diagnosing strange behavior fitted spline. spline behaves oddly, especially extrapolating beyond range time points, please consider adjusting knots spline_knots initial values alpha refitting model.

title: Simulate data. — pmrm_simulate
text: Simulate data progression model repeated measures.

title: Simulate data. — pmrm_simulate
code: pmrm_simulate(   patients,   visit_times,   spline_knots,   spline_method,   tau,   alpha,   beta,   gamma,   sigma,   rho,   slowing,   proportional )

title: Simulate data. — pmrm_simulate
text: patients Positive integer scalar, total number patients output dataset. Patients allocated (roughly) uniformly across study arms. visit_times Numeric vector, continuous scheduled time randomization study visit. spline_knots Numeric vector spline knots continuous scale, including boundary knots. spline_method Character string, spline method use base model. Must "natural" "fmm". See stats::splinefun() details. tau Positive numeric scalar, standard deviation jittering simulated time points. Defaults 0 observed continuous times just scheduled visit times. alpha Numeric vector spline coefficients simulating mean function f(t_{ij} | spline_knots, alpha). Must length(spline_knots) elements. beta Treatment effect parameters. Input format interpretation vary model model. gamma Numeric vector model coefficients covariate adjustment. simulation functions pmrm simulate length(gamma) columns covariate adjustment model matrix W. Set numeric(0) omit covariates. sigma positive numeric vector visit-level standard deviation parameters. rho finite numeric vector correlation parameters. Must length J * (J - 1) / 2, J length(visit_times). full covariance matrix Sigma given diag(sigma) %*% RTMB::unstructured(length(sigma))$corr(rho) %*% diag(sigma).

title: Simulate data. — pmrm_simulate
text: tibble simulated clinical data (see "Simulated data" section).

title: Simulate data. — pmrm_simulate
text: datasets returned simulation functions one row per patient visit following columns conform notation vignette("models", package = "pmrm"): patient: Character vector patient ID labels. visit: Ordered factor clinical visits labels included. min(visit) indicates baseline visit. arm: Ordered factor study arms visits included. min(arm) indicates control arm. : integer ID patient. j: integer ID clinical visit. j == 1 baseline. k: integer ID study arm patient . k == 1 control arm. y: clinical outcomes. t: observed continuous time since baseline. beta: scalar component treatment effect parameter beta defined patient . mu: expected clinical outcome given patient visit. w_*: columns covariate adjustment model matrix W. e: residuals.

text: Simulate dataset non-proportional decline model.

title: Simulate non-proportional decline model. — pmrm_simulate_decline_nonproportional
code: pmrm_simulate_decline_nonproportional(   patients = 300,   visit_times = seq(from = 0, to = 4, by = 1),   spline_knots = visit_times,   spline_method = c("natural", "fmm"),   tau = 0,   alpha = log(spline_knots + 1),   beta = cbind(0, rbind(0, rep(0.2, length(visit_times) - 1L), rep(0.3,     length(visit_times) - 1L))),   gamma = numeric(0L),   sigma = rep(1, length(visit_times)),   rho = rep(0, length(visit_times) * (length(visit_times) - 1L)/2L) )

title: Simulate non-proportional decline model. — pmrm_simulate_decline_nonproportional
text: patients Positive integer scalar, total number patients output dataset. Patients allocated (roughly) uniformly across study arms. visit_times Numeric vector, continuous scheduled time randomization study visit. spline_knots Numeric vector spline knots continuous scale, including boundary knots. spline_method Character string, spline method use base model. Must "natural" "fmm". See stats::splinefun() details. tau Positive numeric scalar, standard deviation jittering simulated time points. Defaults 0 observed continuous times just scheduled visit times. alpha Numeric vector spline coefficients simulating mean function f(t_{ij} | spline_knots, alpha). Must length(spline_knots) elements. beta Numeric matrix one row study arm (including control arm) one column study visit (including baseline). See vignette("models", package = "pmrm") details parameter. gamma Numeric vector model coefficients covariate adjustment. simulation functions pmrm simulate length(gamma) columns covariate adjustment model matrix W. title: Predict new outcomes — predict.pmrm_fit
text: Return expected values, standard errors, confidence intervals new outcomes.

title: Predict new outcomes — predict.pmrm_fit
code: # S3 method for class 'pmrm_fit' predict(object, data = object$data, adjust = TRUE, confidence = 0.95, ...)

title: Predict new outcomes — predict.pmrm_fit
text: object fitted model object class "pmrm_fit". data tibble data frame one row per patient visit. new data making predictions. must columns original fit model, except outcome column can entirely absent. object$data example dataset work. just like original data, except rows missing responses removed, remaining rows sorted patient ID categorical scheduled visit. adjust TRUE FALSE. adjust = TRUE returns estimates inference covariate-adjusted mu_ij values (defined vignette("models", package = "pmrm")) new data. adjust = FALSE instead returns inference mu_ij - W %*% gamma, non-covariate-adjusted predictions useful plotting continuous disease progression trajectory plot.pmrm_fit(). confidence Numeric 0 1, confidence level use 2-sided confidence intervals. ... used.

title: Predict new outcomes — predict.pmrm_fit
text: tibble one row row data argument columns "estimate", "standard_error", "lower", "upper". Columns "lower" "upper" lower upper bounds 2-sided confidence intervals means. (confidence intervals actually truly prediction intervals include variability residuals.)

title: Predict new outcomes — predict.pmrm_fit
code: set.seed(0L)   simulation <- pmrm_simulate_decline_proportional(     visit_times = seq_len(5L) - 1,     gamma = c(1, 2)   )   fit <- pmrm_model_decline_proportional(     data = simulation,     outcome = "y",     time = "t",     patient = "patient",     visit = "visit",     arm = "arm",     covariates = ~ w_1 + w_2   )   new_data <- pmrm_simulate_decline_proportional(     patients = 1,     visit_times = seq_len(5L) - 1,     gamma = c(1, 2)   )   new_data$y <- NULL # Permitted but not strictly necessary.   predict(fit, new_data) #> # A tibble: 5 × 7 #>   arm   visit    time estimate standard_error lower  upper #>   <ord> <ord>   <dbl>    <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 arm_1 visit_1     0    -3.12         0.0704 -3.26 -2.98  #> 2 arm_1 visit_2     1     1.15         0.0698  1.01  1.28  #> 3 arm_1 visit_3     2     3.52         0.0795  3.37  3.68  #> 4 arm_1 visit_4     3    -1.03         0.0827 -1.19 -0.865 #> 5 arm_1 visit_5     4     1.27         0.0836  1.10  1.43
